title: 112_hr1070
content: The "Small Company Capital Formation Act of 2011" allows for the exemption of certain securities. The Securities Act of 1933 is amended to add additional exemptions for small issues, allowing for the offering and sale of securities up to $50,000,000 publicly. The amended Securities Act of 1933 allows for the public offering and sale of securities, with certain conditions such as not being restricted securities, application of civil liability provisions, pre-offering solicitation of interest, and annual filing of audited financial statements with the Commission. The Securities Act of 1933 allows for the public offering of securities with conditions such as annual filing of audited financial statements with the Commission and other requirements determined by the Commission for investor protection and public interest. The Securities Act of 1933 allows for public offering of securities with conditions like annual filing of audited financial statements and other requirements for investor protection. Exemption provisions include corporate governance principles, use of investor funds, and disqualification provisions similar to those in Dodd-Frank regulations. Only certain types of securities may be exempted under adopted rules or regulations. The Securities Act of 1933 allows for public offering of securities with conditions like annual filing of audited financial statements and other requirements for investor protection. Exemption provisions include corporate governance principles, use of investor funds, and periodic disclosures may be required for certain exempted securities. The Small Company Capital Formation Act of 2011 allows for the suspension and termination of certain requirements for issuers. The Commission is required to review and adjust offering amount limitations every 2 years. Amendments are made to the Securities Act of 1933 regarding covered securities under NSMIA. Amendments to the Securities Act of 1933 include changes to subparagraphs and a conforming amendment to section 4(5). The Comptroller General will conduct a study on how state Blue Sky laws impact Regulation A offerings. A report on the findings will be sent to the House Committee on Financial Services and the Senate Committee on Banking within 3 months of the Act's enactment.
